The administration immediately returned to Arab-Israeli peacemaking following the end of the Gulf War; this resulted in the [[Madrid Conference]], later in 1991.Middle East Review of International Affairs Journal Volume 6, No. 1 – March 2002 [http://www.rubincenter.org/2002/03/lasensky-2002-03-07/ Underwriting Peace in the Middle East: U.S. Foreign Policy and the Limits of Economic Inducements] ====Somali Civil War==== {{Main|Somali Civil War}} Faced with a humanitarian disaster in [[Somalia]] that was exacerbated by a complete breakdown in civil order, the United Nations had created the [[UNOSOM I]] mission in April 1992 to aid the situation through humanitarian efforts, though the mission failed.{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/Depts/DPKO/Missions/unosomi.htm |title=UNITED NATIONS OPERATION IN SOMALIA I, UN Dept of Peacekeeping|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=May 22, 2011}} The Bush administration proposed American aid to the region by assisting in creating a secure environment for humanitarian efforts and UN Resolution 794 was unanimously adopted by the [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] on December 3, 1992.Security Council Resolution 794 A [[lame duck (politics)|lame duck]] president, Bush launched [[Operation Restore Hope]] the following day under which the United States would assume command in accordance with Resolution 794.Bush, George H., Address to the Nation on the Situation in Somalia, 4/12/92 Fighting would escalate and continue into the Clinton administration.{{cite journal |journal =[[The Washington Post]] ''(online, January 31)'' |author=Atkinson, Rick| date= 1994 | title = Night of a Thousand Casualties | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/01/31/night-of-a-thousand-casualties/1f0c97b1-1605-46e5-9466-ba3599120c25/ | access-date=November 4, 2015 }} ==== Japan ==== During an April 28, 1989 appearance in the press room of the White House, Bush announced that the U.S. would continue a deal with Japan to produce the FSX advanced fighter jet. He said that promises had been made that American jobs and technology would be safe and the proposal would bolster security for both the U.S. and Japan.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-30/news/mn-2867_1_fsx-japan-s-ambassador-nobuo-matsunaga-japan-s-mitsubishi-heavy-industries|title=Bush Clears Way for FSX Fighter Deal With Japan|date=April 30, 1989|publisher=Los Angeles Times}} On November 21, 1989, Bush signed a measure that guaranteed reparations to Japanese-Americans who were relocated into [[Internment of Japanese Americans|internment camps]] during [[World War II]]. Congress authorized US$20,000 ({{Inflation|US|20000|1989|fmt=eq}}) for each survivor.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-11-22/news/mn-164_1_bush-signs|title=Bush Signs Japanese-American Reparation Guarantee|date=November 22, 1989|publisher=Los Angeles Times}} On March 12, 1990, Bush met for an hour with former [[Prime Minister of Japan]] [[Noboru Takeshita]] to discuss shared economic issues and "the fact that their solution will require extraordinary efforts on both sides of the Pacific."{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1990/03/12/Former-Japanese-Prime-Minister-Meets-Bush/7513637218000/|title=Former Japanese Prime Minister Meets Bush|first=Norman D.|last=Sandler|publisher=UPI}} On December 6, 1991, Japanese Prime Minister [[Kiichi Miyazawa]] apologized to the United States for the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]. The following day—which was the fiftieth anniversary of the attack—Bush accepted Japan's apology for the attack that drew the United States into World War II. Bush urged that progress be made in improving relations between the U.S. and Japan.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1991/12/07/Bush-says-US-appreciates-remorse-of-Japan/6434692082000/|title=Bush says U.S. appreciates 'remorse' of Japan|publisher=UPI|date=December 7, 1991|first=Thomas|last=Ferraro}} ==== Israel ==== On June 18, 1990, [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Marlin Fitzwater]] confirmed President Bush had sent [[Prime Minister of Israel]] [[Yitzhak Shamir]] a letter in which he congratulated the latter on his election and urged him to support the proposed "Shamir initiative for peace", which would involve the participation of Palestinian Arabians in local elections.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1990/06/18/Bush-congratulates-Shamir-pushes-peace-process/4351645681600/|title=Bush congratulates Shamir, pushes peace process|publisher=UPI|date=June 18, 1990}} On June 20, Bush suspended American dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization for the latter's refusal to condemn the Palestinian guerrilla raid of an Israeli beach the previous month.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-06-21/news/mn-118_1_splinter-group|title=Bush Suspends Talks With PLO : Terrorism: President assails the organization's failure to denounce a splinter group's raid on an Israeli beach.|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=June 21, 1990}} On August 11, 1992, following a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister [[Yitzhak Rabin]], Bush announced he would seek the approval of Congress to bestow Israel up to $10 billion in loan guarantees to assist the country with its absorbing of Soviet Union immigrants.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/08/12/Bush-strikes-Israel-loan-deal-with-Rabin/3144713592000/|title=Bush strikes Irael loan deal with Rabin|first=Steven|last=Heilbronner|publisher=UPI|date=August 12, 1992}}{{cite web|url=https://bush41library.tamu.edu/archives/public-papers/4655|title=The President's News Conference With Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel in Kennebunkport|date=August 11, 1992|quote=Literally hundreds of thousands of Jews from Ethiopia and from the former Soviet Union now make their homes in Israel; and this, more than anything else, is what the Jewish state is all about. In this regard, I am extremely pleased to announce that we were able to reach agreement on the basic principles to govern the granting of up to billion in loan guarantees. I've long been committed to supporting Israel in the historic task of absorbing immigrants, and I'm delighted that the Prime Minister and I have agreed to an approach which will assist these new Israelis without frustrating the search for peace. We can thus pursue these two humanitarian goals at one and the same time.}} ===NAFTA=== {{Main|North American Free Trade Agreement}} [[File:Nafta.jpg|thumb|Standing: President [[Carlos Salinas]], President Bush, Prime Minister [[Brian Mulroney]]; Seated: [[Jaime Serra Puche]], [[Carla Hills]], and [[Michael Wilson (Canadian politician)|Michael Wilson]] at the NAFTA Initialing Ceremony, October 1992]] The Bush administration and the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]] [[Canadian Prime Minister]] [[Brian Mulroney]] spearheaded the negotiations of the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA). The agreement would eliminate the majority of [[tariff]]s on products that were traded among the United States, Canada, and Mexico. This would encourage trade among the countries. The treaty also restricted patents, copyrights, and trademarks, and outlined the removal of investment restrictions among the three countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.fedex.com/us/customersupport/ftn/faq/nafta.html?link=4 |publisher=Federal Express|title=Frequently Asked Questions: NAFTA|accessdate=April 11, 2008}} President Bush announced the completion of NAFTA during a Rose Garden appearance on August 12, 1992, calling it the "beginning of a new era".{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/08/12/Bush-announces-new-trade-pact-with-Mexico/2321509303014/|title=Bush announces new trade pact with Mexico|first=Helen|last=Thomas|publisher=UPI|date=August 12, 1992}} The agreement came under heavy scrutiny amongst mainly Democrats, who charged that NAFTA resulted in a loss of American jobs. NAFTA also contained no provisions for labor rights; according to the Bush administration, the trade agreement would generate economic resources necessary to enable Mexico's government to overcome problems of funding and enforcement of its labor laws. Bush needed a renewal of negotiating authority to move forward with the NAFTA trade talks. Such authority would enable the president to negotiate a trade accord that would be submitted to Congress for a vote, thereby avoiding a situation in which the president would be required to renegotiate with trading partners those parts of an agreement that Congress wished to change.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/2001/nafta/nafta0401-04.htm|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=April 11, 2008|title= The NAFTA Labor Side Accord}} While initial signing was possible during his term, negotiations made slow, but steady, progress. President Clinton would go on to make the passage of NAFTA a priority for his administration, despite its conservative and Republican roots—with the addition of two side agreements—to achieve its passage in 1993.{{cite web | url = http://www.law.duke.edu/lib/researchguides/nafta.html|title=NAFTA|publisher=Duke University|accessdate=July 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080420094150/http://www.law.duke.edu/lib/researchguides/nafta.html |archive-date=April 20, 2008}} The treaty has since been defended as well as criticized further. The American economy has grown 54% since the adoption of NAFTA in 1993, with 25 million new jobs created; this was seen by some as evidence of NAFTA being beneficial to the United States.{{cite news|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/29/AR2008022902608.html | title= Stop Hating on NAFTA|work=The Washington Post|author=Gutierrez, Carlos M|date= March 1, 2008 | accessdate =April 11, 2008}} With talk in early 2008 regarding a possible American withdrawal from the treaty, [[Carlos M. Gutierrez]], current [[United States Secretary of Commerce]], writes, "Quitting NAFTA would send economic shock waves throughout the world, and the damage would start here at home." But John J. Sweeney, President of the AFL-CIO, wrote in ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' that "the [[U.S. trade deficit]] with Canada and Mexico ballooned to 12 times its pre-NAFTA size, reaching $111 billion in 2004."{{cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/views05/0321-31.htm|title=A Bad Deal on Free Trade|author=Sweeney, John J|work=Boston Globe|publisher=Common Dreams News Center|accessdate=April 11, 2008|date=March 21, 2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915030224/http://www.commondreams.org/views05/0321-31.htm |archive-date=September 15, 2008}} ===Pardons=== {{Main|List of people pardoned by George H. W. Bush}} In keeping with tradition, Bush issued a series of pardons during his last days in office. On December 24, 1992, he granted executive clemency to six former government employees implicated in the Iran-Contra scandal of the late 1980s, most prominently former Secretary of Defense [[Caspar Weinberger]].{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/news/iran/1992/921224-260039.htm |title=Bush pardons Weinberger, Five Other Tied to Iran-Contra |accessdate=April 11, 2008 |publisher=Federation of American Scientists |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421150512/http://www.fas.org/news/iran/1992/921224-260039.htm |archivedate=April 21, 2008 |df=mdy }} Bush described Weinberger, who was scheduled to stand trial on January 5, 1993, for criminal charges related to Iran-Contra, as a "true American patriot". In addition to Weinberger, Bush pardoned Duane R. Clarridge, Clair E. George, [[Robert C. McFarlane]], [[Elliott Abrams]], and Alan G. Fiers Jr., all of whom had been indicted and/or convicted of criminal charges by an [[United States Office of the Independent Counsel|Independent Counsel]] headed by Lawrence Walsh.{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/pardon/bushgrants.htm|title=Pardons and Commutations Granted by President George H. W. Bush|publisher=United States Department of Justice|accessdate=May 17, 2008}} ===Honorary degrees=== George H.W. W. Bush Awarded Honorary Degree – National Intelligence University |publisher=Ni-u.edu |date=March 23, 2016 |accessdate=October 28, 2017}} |} {{Expand list|date=April 2018}} ===Awards and honors=== In 1990, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]] ''magazine named him the [[Time Man of the Year|Man of the Year]]. In 1991, the U.S. Navy Memorial Foundation awarded Bush its Lone Sailor award for his naval service and his subsequent government service. In 1993, he was made an Honorary [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] by Queen Elizabeth II.{{cite web|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/output/page4883.asp|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530062826/http://www.royal.gov.uk/output/page4883.asp|archivedate=May 30, 2008|title=Honours: Order of the Bath|publisher=The British Monarchy Today|accessdate=March 28, 2008}} In 2009, he received the [[PGA Tour Lifetime Achievement Award]]. ===1992 presidential campaign=== {{Main|United States presidential election, 1992}} In early 1992, Bush announced that he would seek a second term. A coalition victory in the Persian Gulf War and high approval ratings made re-election seem likely. As a result, many leading Democrats declined to seek their party's presidential nomination. On the negative side, Bush's popularity was reduced by an economic recession and doubts of whether he properly ended the Gulf War. Conservative political columnist [[Pat Buchanan]] challenged Bush for the Republican nomination. He shocked political pundits by finishing second, with 37% of the vote in the New Hampshire primary. Bush responded by adopting more conservative positions on issues, in an attempt to undermine Buchanan's base. Once he had secured the nomination, Bush faced his Democratic challenger, [[Governor of Arkansas|Arkansas Governor]] [[Bill Clinton]]. Clinton attacked Bush as a politician who was not doing enough to assist the working middle-class and being "out of touch" with the common man, a notion reinforced by reporter [[Andrew Rosenthal]]'s false report that Bush was "astonished" to see a demonstration of a supermarket [[barcode reader|scanner]].{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/history/american/bushscan.htm |title=Maybe I'm Amazed |date=April 1, 2001 |accessdate=April 11, 2008 |publisher=Snopes.com |archivedate=May 27, 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120527030747/http://www.snopes.com/history/american/bushscan.asp |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} [[File:ElectoralCollege1992.svg|upright=1.35|thumb|The 1992 presidential electoral votes by state]] In early 1992, the race took an unexpected twist when Texas billionaire [[H. Ross Perot]] launched a third party bid, claiming that neither Republicans nor Democrats could eliminate the deficit and make government more efficient. His message appealed to voters across the political spectrum disappointed with both parties' perceived fiscal irresponsibility.{{cite web|title=The Perot Vote|publisher=President and Fellows of Harvard College|accessdate=April 23, 2008|url=http://www.hks.harvard.edu/case/3pt/perot_vote.html}} Perot later bowed out of the race for a short time, then reentered.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEED71331F934A15753C1A964958260|title=The 1992 Campaign: The Independent; Bush Aide calls Perot's story 'paranoid'|date=October 27, 1992|accessdate=April 14, 2008|work=The New York Times|author=Holmes, Steven A}} Clinton had originally been in the lead, until Perot reentered, tightening the race significantly.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE5DC1E3AF936A15753C1A964958260|title=The 1992 Campaign: The Overview; Contest tightens as Perot Resurges and Clinton slips|accessdate=April 14, 2008|date=October 25, 1992|work=The New York Times|author=Toner, Robin}} As Election Day neared, the polls suggested that the race was a dead-heat, but Clinton pulled out on top, with 370 electoral votes to Bush's 168 votes. Perot won 19% of the popular vote, one of the highest totals for a third party candidate in U.S. history, drawing equally from both major candidates, according to exit polls.{{cite news|last=Holmes |first=Steven A. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE0DB1F3FF936A35752C1A964958260 |title=THE 1992 ELECTIONS: DISAPPOINTMENT – NEWS ANALYSIS An Eccentric but No Joke; Perot's Strong Showing Raises Questions On What Might Have Been, and Might Be – |work=The New York Times |date=November 5, 1992 |accessdate=September 5, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://millercenter.org/academic/americanpresident/bush/essays/biography/3|title=George Herbert Walker Bush: Campaigns and Elections|accessdate=April 11, 2008|publisher=Miller Center of Public Affairs|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409120342/http://millercenter.org/academic/americanpresident/bush/essays/biography/3|archivedate=April 9, 2008|df=mdy-all}} Several key factors led to Bush's defeat. The ailing economy that arose from recession may have been the main factor in Bush's loss. On Election Day, 7 in 10 voters said that the economy was either "not so good" or "poor".{{cite news|author=R. W. Apple Jr. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE5D81439F937A35752C1A964958260 |title=THE 1992 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS; The Economy's Casualty – |location=Pennsylvania; Ohio; New England States (Us); Michigan; West Coast; New Jersey; Middle East |work=The New York Times |date=November 4, 1992 |accessdate=September 5, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/06/09/BUGBI72U8Q1.DTL&type=business|title=Downside of the Reagan Legacy|work=The San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=April 11, 2008|author=Lazarus, David|date=June 9, 2004}} On the eve of the 1992 election, after unemployment reports of 7.8% appeared (the highest since 1984),{{cite journal | author = WSJ Research | year = 2015 | journal = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | title = How the Presidents Stack Up: A Look at U.S. Presidents' Job Approval Ratings (George H.W. Bush) | url=https://www.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/info-presapp0605-31.html | accessdate=November 4, 2015}} Economic [[recession]] had contributed to a sharp decline in his approval rating – to just 37%.{{cite web|url=http://www.pollingreport.com/whitejk.htm |title=Presidency on Life Support |publisher=Pollingreport.com |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} Conservative Republicans pointed out that Bush's 1990 agreement to raise taxes contradicted his famous "[[Read my lips: no new taxes]]" pledge. In doing so, Bush alienated many members of his conservative base, losing their support for his re-election. According to one survey, of the voters who cited Bush's broken "No New Taxes" pledge as "very important", two thirds voted for Bill Clinton.{{cite news |first=Jeffrey |last=Schmalz |title=Clinton Carves a Path Deep Into Reagan Country |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEFD8173FF937A35752C1A964958260 |work=The New York Times |date=November 4, 1992 |accessdate=May 21, 2008 }} Bush had raised taxes in an attempt to address an increasing budget deficit, which has largely been attributed to the Reagan tax cuts and military spending of the 1980s. The tax revenue increase had not hurt his approval ratings to the extent that it prevented it from reaching 89% during the [[Gulf War]], four months after the tax vote.[http://www.tnr.com/blog/plank/110499/the-illusory-power-grover-norquist The Illusory Power of Grover Norquist]| Timothy Noah| November 27, 2012 By February 1991 his approval rating rose to its highest level—89%.[http://www.gallup.com/poll/116677/presidential-approval-ratings-gallup-historical-statistics-trends.aspx Presidential Approval Ratings – Gallup Historical Statistics and Trends] Gallup.com ===Public image=== [[File:US Navy 051008-N-9274T-001 After arriving on board Naval Air Station Joint Reserve Base (NAS JRB), New Orleans, former President George H. Bush sits down to eat with military personnel.jpg|thumb|Bush visits [[Naval Air Station Joint Reserve Base New Orleans|NAS JRB]], New Orleans personnel before he receives briefs on the status of [[Joint Task Force Katrina]] relief efforts, October 2005]] George Bush was widely seen as a "pragmatic caretaker" president who lacked a unified and compelling long-term theme in his efforts.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/presidents/george-h-w-bush-1482924.html |title=The Independent, ' ' George H. W. Bush |work=The Independent |location=UK |date= January 22, 2009|accessdate=September 5, 2010 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/54609/michael-howard/the-prudence-thing-george-bush-s-class-act |title=The Prudence Thing: George Bush's Class Act |work=Foreign Affairs |date=November 1, 1998 |accessdate=September 5, 2010}}{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,963342-2,00.html | work=Time | title=Where Is the Real George Bush? | date=January 26, 1987 | accessdate=May 3, 2010 | first=Robert | last=Ajemian}} Indeed, Bush's [[sound bite]] where he refers to the issue of overarching purpose as "the vision thing" has become a [[metonym]] applied to other political figures accused of similar difficulties.{{cite web|url=http://www.askoxford.com/worldofwords/quotations/phrasefable/visionthing/?view=uk |title=Quotations : Oxford Dictionaries Online |publisher=Askoxford.com |accessdate=July 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030204213218/http://www.askoxford.com/worldofwords/quotations/phrasefable/visionthing/?view=uk |archive-date=February 4, 2003}}{{cite book |title=Listen Up, Mr. President: Everything You Always Wanted Your President to Know and Do | isbn = 978-1-4391-4815-0 | author = Helen Thomas |author2=Craig Crawford | publisher = Scribner }}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joseph-a-palermo/meg-whitmans-vision-thing_b_300845.html |title=Joseph A. Palermo: Meg Whitman's "Vision Thing" |work=Huffington Post |accessdate=September 5, 2010 |date=September 26, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20090929/NEWS02/909290341/1003/NEWS02 |title=It's time to do the 'vision' thing: Times Argus Online |publisher=Timesargus.com |date=September 29, 2009 |accessdate=September 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130204102054/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20090929/NEWS02/909290341/1003/NEWS02 |archivedate=February 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|author=Zbigniew Mazurak |url=http://www.therealitycheck.org/?p=7492 |title=Blog Archive » Sarah Palin as a GOP Nominee? |publisher=The Reality Check |accessdate=September 5, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://rothkopf.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2009/10/01/barack_obama_does_not_want_to_become_known_as_the_great_ditherer |title=Obama does not want to become known as 'The Great Ditherer' | first = David | last = Rothkopf | date = October 1, 2009 |work=Foreign Policy |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} "He does not say why he wants to be there", wrote columnist George Will, "so the public does not know why it should care if he gets his way". His [[Ivy League]] and prep school education led to warnings by advisors that his image was too "[[preppy]]" in 1980, which resulted in deliberate efforts in his 1988 campaign to shed the image, including meeting voters at factories and shopping malls, abandoning set speeches. His ability to gain broad international support for the [[Gulf War]] and the war's result were seen as both a diplomatic and military triumph, rousing bipartisan approval,{{cite web|url=http://people-press.org/report/182/modest-bush-approval-rating-boost-at-wars-end |title=Modest Bush Approval Rating Boost at War's End: Summary of Findings – Pew Research Center for the People & the Press |publisher=People-press.org |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} though his decision to withdraw without removing [[Saddam Hussein]] left mixed feelings, and attention returned to the domestic front and a souring economy.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/bush41/program/intro.html |work=American Experience|title=George H. W. Bush |publisher=PBS |date=October 3, 1990 |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} A ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' article mistakenly depicted Bush as being surprised to see a supermarket [[barcode reader]];{{cite journal | author=Goldberg, Jonah | date=August 22, 2008 | title=The Corner: The Supermarket Scanner Story Cont'd | journal = [[National Review]] | url = http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/167613/supermarket-scanner-story-contd-jonah-goldberg | access-date=June 26, 2017 }}{{cite journal | author=Rosenthal, Andrew | date=February 5, 1992| title=Bush Encounters the Supermarket, Amazed | journal = [[The New York Times]] | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/05/us/bush-encounters-the-supermarket-amazed.html | access-date=November 5, 2015 }} the report of his reaction exacerbated the notion that he was "out of touch". Amid the [[early 1990s recession]], his image shifted from "conquering hero" to "politician befuddled by economic matters". Although Bush became the first elected Republican president since Hoover in [[United States presidential election, 1932|1932]] to lose a reelection bid (facing a 34% approval rating leading up to the 1992 election), the mood did not last. Despite his defeat, Bush climbed back from election day approval levels to leave office in 1993 with a 56% job approval rating.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/sections/politics/DailyNews/poll%5Fclintonlegacy010117.html|title=Poll: Clinton Legacy Mixed|author=Langer, Gary|publisher=ABC News|date=January 17, 2001|accessdate=April 11, 2008}} By December 2008, 60% of Americans gave Bush's presidency a positive rating.{{cite news|author=Paul Steinhauser|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/01/07/polls.former.presidents/index.html#cnnSTCText |title=CNN, Views soften on 2 former presidents, CNN poll finds |publisher=CNN |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} ==Post-presidency (1993–present)== ===Clinton presidency=== Upon leaving office, Bush retired with his wife, Barbara, and temporarily moved into a friend's house near the [[Tanglewood, Houston|Tanglewood]] community of Houston as they prepared to build a permanent retirement house nearby."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=26kkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fQcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5357,12289 From White House to 'regular house']". [[Associated Press]] at the ''[[Ocala Star-Banner]]''. Saturday November 21, 1992. 2A. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] (2 of 84) on October 14, 2012. Ultimately they built their retirement house in the community of [[West Oaks, Houston|West Oaks]], near Tanglewood. They had a presidential office within the Park Laureate Building on [[Memorial Drive (Houston)|Memorial Drive]]."[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ST&s_site=dfw&p_multi=ST&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF8EDE5F8E0428&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D Bushes upbeat for step-down]". ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]''. January 10, 1993. 1 News. Retrieved on October 15, 2012. "Bush's Houston office will be in the Park Laureate Building on Memorial Drive" Mimi Swartz of ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' wrote that "The Bushes are too studiously sedate to live in [[River Oaks, Houston|River Oaks]]".Swartz, Mimi. "[http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0603/feature8/ Survival of the Richest]." ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]''. March 2006. Retrieved on June 4, 2014. They spend the summer at [[Bush compound|Walker's Point]] in [[Kennebunkport, Maine]]. In 1993, Bush was awarded an honorary [[knighthood]] ([[Order of the Bath|GCB]]) by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]]. He was the third American president to receive the honor, the others being Dwight D. Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan. In 1993, Bush was targeted in an assassination plot when he visited Kuwait to commemorate the coalition's victory over Iraq in the Gulf War. Kuwaiti authorities arrested 17 people who were allegedly involved in using a car bomb to kill Bush. Through interviews with the suspects and examinations of the bomb's circuitry and wiring, the FBI established that the plot had been directed by the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]]. A Kuwaiti court later convicted all but one of the defendants. Two months later, Clinton retaliated when he ordered the [[Cruise missile strikes on Iraq (1993)|firing]] of 23 [[cruise missiles]] at Iraqi Intelligence Service headquarters in [[Baghdad]]. The day before the strike, U.S. Ambassador to the UN [[Madeleine Albright]] went before the Security Council to present evidence of the Iraqi plot. After the missiles were fired, Vice President [[Al Gore]] said the attack "was intended to be a proportionate response at the place where this plot" to assassinate Bush "was hatched and implemented".{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/longroad/etc/assassination.html |title=frontline: the long road to war: assassination |publisher=PBS |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} In September 1993, Bush and other living former presidents were invited back to the White House for an Arab-Israeli peace accord. They also made the case to Clinton for a repeal of [[NAFTA]].{{cite book|title=Destiny and Power: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush|first=Jon|last=Meacham|page=543|year=2015|isbn=978-1400067657|publisher=Random House}} In April 1994, Bush attended the [[Death and state funeral of Richard Nixon|funeral of Richard Nixon]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/28/us/37th-president-overview-nixon-buried-note-praise-reconciliation.html|title=The 37th President|first=Maureen|last=Dowd|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 28, 1994}} In the 1994 gubernatorial elections, his sons George W. and Jeb concurrently ran for [[Governor of Texas]] and [[Governor of Florida]]. The elder Bush frequently telephoned campaign headquarters for updates on the race.Meacham, p. 549. George W. won his race against [[Ann Richards]] while Jeb lost to [[Lawton Chiles]]. After the results came in, the elder Bush told ABC, "I have very mixed emotions. Proud father, is the way I would sum it all up."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/09/us/1994-elections-nation-bushes-texas-elects-george-w-while-florida-rejects-jeb.html|title=THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE NATION THE BUSHES; Texas Elects George W. While Florida Rejects Jeb|date=November 9, 1994|first=Sam Howe|last=Verhovek}} Jeb would again run for governor of Florida in 1998 and win at the same time that his brother George W. won re-election in Texas just two years prior to his election as President. From 1993 to 1999 he served as the chairman of the board of trustees for [[Eisenhower Fellowships]], and from 2007 to 2009 was chairman of the [[National Constitution Center]]. On September 28, 1994, Bush said he was opposed to sending American troops to [[Haiti]], citing his loss of confidence in [[President of Haiti]] [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]] while speaking to business and civic leaders in [[Houston]].{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1994/09/28/Bush-has-lost-confidence-in-Aristide/2821780724800/|title=Bush has lost confidence in Aristide|first=Paula|last=Dittrick|date=September 28, 1994|publisher=UPI}} In an October 22, 1994 speech in [[Cancun, Mexico]], Bush said history would vindicate him for not attempting to force Saddam Hussein out of power while in office: "The Mideast peace talks that offer hope to the world would never have started if we had done that. The Arabs would never have talked to us."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/23/world/bush-on-iraq.html|title=Bush on Iraq|date=October 23, 1994|work=[[The New York Times]]}} On July 17, 1995, Bush returned to the White House for the unveiling of his official portrait in an East Room ceremony attended by former members of his administration.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/us/bush-portraits-unveiled-at-white-house.html|title=Bush Portraits Unveiled at White House|date=July 18, 1995|work=[[The New York Times]]}} In September 1995, Bush met with [[President of Vietnam]] [[Lê Đức Anh]] and party secretary [[Đỗ Mười]] in [[Vietnam]].{{cite book|last=Bush|first=Barbara|title=Reflections: Life After the White House|publisher=Scribner|year=2004|isbn=978-0743255820|pages=85–86}} On September 2, Bush and his son George W. participated in a parade commemorating World War II in [[Fredericksburg, Texas]], where the elder Bush reasoned the US had become united in the aftermath of the [[Pearl Harbor attack]] and stressed America would have to stay involved in world affairs to continue its unity.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1995/09/02/Bush-US-united-by-world-involvement/9398810014400/|title=Bush: U.S. united by world involvement|date=September 2, 1995|publisher=UPI}} On July 26, 1996, Bush met with Republican presidential candidate [[Bob Dole]] and pledged he would do everything in his power to aid in securing a victory for Dole in the upcoming [[1996 United States Presidential election|presidential election]].{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1996/07/26/Bush-vows-to-help-Dole-win-White-House/9683838353600/?spt=su|title=Bush vows to help Dole win White House|date=July 26, 1996|publisher=UPI}} The two met again in October while Dole was preparing for upcoming debates with President Clinton. Bush's experience with debating Clinton prompting Dole to seek out his advice.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/06/us/dole-concludes-debate-preparation-by-asking-bush-for-advice.html|title=Dole Concludes Debate Preparation by Asking Bush for Advice|date=October 6, 1996|work=[[The New York Times]]}} In 1997, the Houston Intercontinental Airport was renamed [[George Bush Intercontinental Airport]]. In February 1997, Bush endorsed the chemical weapon banning treaty supported by [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Madeleine Albright]], saying the US would need to approve the treaty ahead of the April deadline.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world/bush-backs-albright-on-chemical-arms-ban.html|title=Bush Backs Albright on Chemical Arms Ban|date=February 9, 1997|work=[[The New York Times]]}} In April 1997, Bush gave a speech at a convocation of a weekend conference analyzing his presidency{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/20/us/bush-is-a-self-effacing-figure-at-meeting-on-his-leadership.html|title=Bush Is a Self-Effacing Figure At Meeting on His Leadership|first=Clifford|last=Krauss|date=April 20, 1997|work=[[The New York Times]]}} and joined President [[Bill Clinton]], former President Ford, and Nancy Reagan in signing the "Summit Declaration of Commitment" in advocating for participation by private citizens in solving domestic issues within the United States.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/us/presidents-call-for-big-citizenship-not-big-government.html|title=Presidents Call for Big Citizenship, Not Big Government|first=James|last=Bennet|date=April 29, 1997|work=[[The New York Times]]}} In August 1997, Bush agreed to be interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'', as long as he would not be portrayed as giving credit to himself over the balanced budget deal that was composed by President Clinton and House Speaker [[Newt Gingrich]]. During a telephone interview, he stated his belief that history would show that his administration laid the groundwork for the agreement .{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/08/us/in-balanced-budget-deal-bush-is-off-the-seesaw.html|title=In Balanced-Budget Deal, Bush Is Off the Seesaw|first=David E.|last=Rosenbaum|date=August 8, 1997}} President Bush is Honorary Chairman of [[Points of Light]], an international nonprofit dedicated to engaging more people and resources in solving serious social problems through voluntary service.{{cite web|title=Points of Light: Our Leadership|url=http://www.pointsoflight.org/our-leadership#bm|publisher=Points of Light|accessdate=May 23, 2013}} In January 1999, Bush spoke in the Old Senate chamber as part of a lecture series for Senators in an address warning against the collapse of political decorum and invasions into the privacy of individuals.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/21/us/state-union-ex-president-speech-senators-bush-laments-decline-civility-privacy.html|title=STATE OF THE UNION: THE EX-PRESIDENT; In Speech to Senators, Bush Laments Decline of Civility and Privacy|first=Frank|last=Bruni|date=January 21, 1999|work=[[The New York Times]]}} In February 1999, Bush was part of the American delegation to the funeral of [[Hussein of Jordan]] in [[Amman]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/09/world/death-king-americans-clinton-lauds-king-hussein-man-vision-spirit.html|title=DEATH OF A KING: THE AMERICANS; Clinton Lauds King Hussein As Man of Vision and Spirit|first=John|last=Broder|date=February 9, 1999|work=[[The New York Times]]}} In April 1999, Bush called for the release of former Chilean dictator [[Augusto Pinochet]] when [[Indictment and arrest of Augusto Pinochet|Spain had him arrested]] and sought to try him for human rights violations.{{cite web |title=Former U.S. President Bush urges Pinochet release |url=http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/chile/bush.htm |publisher=CNN |via=Reuters |date=April 12, 1999 |accessdate=December 11, 2017}} In May 1999, Bush and his wife Barbara honored six senior citizens during the annual Ageless Heroes honors in [[Chicago, Illinois]].{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1999/05/18/Bush-honors-senior-ageless-heroes/8710927000000/|title=Bush honors senior 'ageless heroes'|date=May 18, 1999|publisher=UPI}} === George W. Bush presidency === [[File:G & B. Bush F-SD-03-15575.jpg|left|thumb|upright=0.9|George and Barbara Bush, 2001]] His eldest son, [[George W. Bush]], was inaugurated as the 43rd president of the United States on January 20, 2001, and re-elected in 2004. Through previous administrations, the elder Bush had ubiquitously been known as "George Bush" or "President Bush", but following his son's election the need to distinguish between them has made [[retronym]]ic forms such as "George H. W. Bush" and "George Bush senior" and colloquialisms such as "Bush 41" and "Bush the Elder" much more common. H.W. Bush was traveling to [[Minnesota]] for a speaking engagement on the day of the [[September 11 attacks]]. George W. made multiple calls to get in contact with his father before the two men reconnected after the elder Bush had gone to a [[Brookfield, Wisconsin]] motel.{{cite book|title=41: A Portrait of My Father|first=George W.|last=Bush|authorlink=George W. Bush|publisher=Crown Publishers|isbn=978-0553447781|page=265.}} Bush told biographer [[Jon Meacham]] that his son's vice president, Dick Cheney, underwent a change following the September 11 attacks: "His seeming knuckling under to the real hard-charging guys who want to fight about everything, use force to get our way in the Middle East.”{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/05/us/politics/elder-bush-says-his-son-was-served-badly-by-aides.html|title=Elder Bush Says His Son Was Served Badly by Aides|date=November 4, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Peter|last=Baker}} In December 2002, George W. sought counsel from the elder Bush regarding Iraq and informed him of "my efforts to rally the Saudis, Jordanians, Turks, and others in the Middle East".Meacham, pp. 571-572. Following the fall of Baghdad, Bush praised George W. in an April 2003 email to the incumbent president.Meacham, p. 274. In a September 14, 2003 interview with BBC, Bush stated his support for a continuation of his son's war against terrorism and the US was in a better state in terms of protecting itself from terrorism than two years prior.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2003/09/14/Ex-president-Bush-backs-war-on-terrorism/87711063557337/|title=Ex-president Bush backs war on terrorism|date=September 14, 2003|publisher=UPI}} While visiting Houston VA Medical Center on December 17, Bush told reporters of his satisfaction with the capture of Saddam Hussein.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2003/12/17/Elder-Bush-says-capture-magical-moment/99301071700689/|title=Elder Bush says capture magical moment|publisher=UPI|date=December 17, 2003}} President and Mrs. Bush attended the [[Death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan|state funeral of Ronald Reagan]] in June 2004,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/12/us/the-40th-president-faces-in-the-four-thousand.html|title=The 40th President; Faces in the Four Thousand|date=June 12, 2004|first=Brian|last=Wingfield}} and [[Death and state funeral of Gerald Ford|of Gerald Ford]] in January 2007.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/03/us/03ford.html|title=Ford Is Remembered at Funeral in Washington|first=Scott|last=Shane|date=January 3, 2007|work=[[The New York Times]]}} One month later, he was awarded the [[Ronald Reagan Freedom Award]] in [[Beverly Hills, California]], by former First Lady [[Nancy Reagan]]. Despite Bush's political differences with Bill Clinton, reports have acknowledged that the two former presidents have become friends.{{cite news|last=Healy |first=Patrick |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/19/us/politics/19memo.html |title=A Candidacy That May Test a Friendship's Ties |work=The New York Times |date=May 19, 2007 |accessdate=May 22, 2011}} He and Clinton appeared together in television ads in 2005, encouraging aid for victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]] and the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]].{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/PersonOfWeek/story?id=1446477 |title= People of the Year: Bill Clinton and George H. W. Bush |publisher=ABC News|date=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} In October 2004, Bush endorsed [[Pete Sessions]] and [[Ted Poe]] in Texas congressional races.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2004/10/27/Pa-Bush-endorses-another-Texas-candidate/13741098887403/|title=Pa Bush endorses another Texas candidate|date=October 27, 2004|publisher=UPI}} In February 2006, Bush delivered a eulogy at the funeral of [[Coretta Scott King]].{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2006/02/07/4-US-presidents-at-Coretta-King-funeral/36691139346252/|title=4 U.S. presidents at Coretta King funeral|date=February 7, 2006|publisher=UPI}} On March 2, 2006, President Bush announced that his father would lead the American delegation to the inauguration of President-elect of the Republic of Portugal [[Anibal Cavaco Silva]].{{cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/03/20060302.html|title=President Announces Former President Bush to Lead U.S. Delegation to Attend Portuguese Inauguration|website=georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov}} In September 2006, Bush campaigned for New Jersey Senate candidate [[Thomas Kean Jr.]], praising him as well as stating his respect for Kean calling on the resignation of US Defense Secretary Rumsfeld.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE1DF1731F934A3575AC0A9609C8B63|title=Two Ex-Presidents, Often Allies, Are Divided by a Senate Race|date=September 7, 2006|publisher=''New York Times''}} Kean went on to lose the election. The following month, he was honored by the [[National Italian American Foundation]] (NIAF) with the NIAF One America Award for fundraising, with Bill Clinton, for the victims of the [[2004 tsunami]] and [[Hurricane Katrina]].{{cite web |url=http://www.niaf.org/news/index.asp?id=782 |title=Univision CEO Joe Uva to Receive One America Award |publisher=National Italian American Foundation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612022655/http://niaf.org/news/index.asp?id=782 |archive-date=June 12, 2012 |accessdate=July 30, 2016}} On February 18, 2008, Bush formally endorsed Senator [[John McCain]] for President of the United States.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/18/AR2008021800930.html|title=George H. W. Bush Endorses McCain for President|date=February 18, 2008|accessdate=March 28, 2008|work=The Washington Post}} The endorsement offered a boost to McCain's campaign, because the [[Arizona]] Senator had been facing criticism among many conservatives.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-campaign19feb19,0,856707.story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314155546/http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-campaign19feb19%2C0%2C856707.story |archivedate=March 14, 2008 |title=Former President Bush Endorses McCain |date=February 18, 2008 |accessdate=March 28, 2008 |work=Los Angeles Times |author=Neuman, Johanna |deadurl=yes |df= }} During a trip to [[Tokyo, Japan]], Bush said that he would campaign vigorously against Senator [[Hillary Clinton]] if she were to initiate a presidential bid.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2006/12/16/Elder-Bush-Beat-the-hell-out-of-Hillary/26041166298156/|title=Elder Bush: 'Beat the hell' out of Hillary|publisher=UPI}} In March 2008, Bush met with [[President of the People's Republic of China]] [[Hu Jintao]], who praised Bush for his attempts at harmonizing relations between the US and China.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/03/08/Former-US-president-Bush-visits-China/11991205012399/|title=Former U.S. president Bush visits China|date=March 8, 2008|publisher=UPI}} During an address at the [[University of Kansas]] on November 16, 2008, Bush said that President-elect Obama would encounter diverse issues upon taking office and experience a wave of enthusiasm.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/11/17/Elder-Bush-says-Obama-will-face-tough-job/78081226934880/|title=Elder Bush says Obama will face tough job|date=November 17, 2008|publisher=UPI}} On January 10, 2009, George H. W. and George W. Bush were both present at the commissioning of {{USS|George H.W. Bush|CVN-77}}, the tenth and last {{sclass-|Nimitz|aircraft carrier|0}} [[supercarrier]] of the [[United States Navy]].{{cite web |title=Future USS George H. W. Bush to Transit|publisher=Naval Sea Systems Command Public Affairs|date=December 18, 2008 |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=41503|accessdate=December 22, 2008 }}{{cite news|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2009/01/carrier-awaits-call-come-life-ceremony-today|title=Carrier awaits a call to come to life in ceremony today|last=Jones|first=Matthew|date=January 10, 2009|work=The Virginian Pilot|publisher=Landmark Communications|accessdate=January 10, 2009}} Bush paid a visit to the carrier again on May 26, 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=45678|title=Former President Bush Visits Namesake Aircraft Carrier}} ===Obama presidency=== In June 2009, Bush came out in support for [[Sonia Sotomayor]] to receive fair hearings in her nomination for Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. "She was called by somebody a racist once. That's not right. I mean, that's not fair. It doesn't help the process. You're out there name-calling. So let them decide who they want to vote for and get on with it."{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/06/12/Bush-defends-Sotomayor-nomination/38421244850651/|title=Bush defends Sotomayor nomination |date=June 12, 2009|publisher=UPI}} In October 2009, Bush criticized the rampant criticism of the current times, reflecting that he did not receive such "day in and day out" during his presidency and named [[Keith Olbermann]] and [[Rachel Maddow]] of [[MSNBC]] as examples; he called the two "sick puppies."{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/elder-bush-decries-lack-of-civility-in-politics/|title=Elder Bush Decries Lack of Civility in Politics|date=October 16, 2009|publisher=CBS News}} Also during that month, on October 16, Bush joined President [[Barack Obama]] onstage at [[Texas A&M University]] for a promotion of volunteering.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/17/us/politics/17obama.html|title=Two Presidents Share a Stage on the Subject of Service |date=October 16, 2009|first=Peter|last=Baker|work=[[The New York Times]]}} Following in the footsteps of his father and grandfather, Bush was an avid golfer. In 2011, he was inducted in the [[World Golf Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldgolfhalloffame.org/george-h-w-bush/|title=Bush, George H.W. |accessdate=June 1, 2018}} On February 15, 2011, he was awarded the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]—the highest civilian honor in the United States—by President [[Barack Obama]].For the transcript of Obama's remarks honoring Bush, see {{cite web |url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/photos-and-video/video/2011/02/15/2010-presidential-medal-freedom-ceremony |title=2010 Presidential Medal of Freedom Ceremony |publisher=The White House |date=February 15, 2011 }} On March 29, 2012, Bush endorsed [[Mitt Romney]] for the Republican presidential nomination in the 2012 Presidential election. [[NBC News]] reported that Bush had chosen to support Romney three months prior.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/George-HW-Bush-endorses-Romney/52521333006200/|title=George H.W. Bush endorses Romney|date=March 29, 2012|publisher=UPI}} In July 2013, Bush had his head shaved in a show of support for the two-year-old son of a member of his security detail, who had [[leukemia]].{{cite news|last=Edwards|first=Breanna|title=George H.W. Bush shaves head |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/07/george-hw-bush-shaves-head-94700.html|newspaper=Politico|date=July 24, 2013}} On July 7, Bush met with Gabrielle Giffords for part of her week-long Rights and Responsibilities Tour advocating expanded background checks in relation to firearm purchases.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2013/07/07/Giffords-meets-with-George-HW-Bush/66501373207418/|title=Giffords meets with George H.W. Bush|publisher=UPI|date=July 7, 2013}} In April 2014, Frederick D. McClure, chief executive of the Bush library foundation, organized a three-day gathering in [[The Woodlands, Texas|College Park, Texas]], to mark the 25th anniversary of the Bush administration. Also in early 2014, the [[John F. Kennedy]] Library Foundation presented the [[Profile in Courage Award]] to Bush and [[Mount Vernon]] awarded him its first [[Cyrus A. Ansary]] Prize.[[Peter Baker (author)|Baker, Peter]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/04/us/politics/hindsight-proves-kinder-and-gentler-to-bush-41.html "Bush 41 Reunion Looks to Burnish His Legacy"], ''New York Times'', April 3, 2014. Retrieved April 4, 2014. The Kennedy foundation award was presented by [[Jack Schlossberg]], the late president's grandson, to [[Lauren Bush Lauren]], who accepted on her grandfather's behalf.Edelman, Adam, [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/george-h-w-bush-honored-kennedy-profile-courage-award-article-1.1779221 "George H.W. Bush honored with Kennedy Profile in Courage Award"], New York ''Daily News'', May 4, 2014. Retrieved June 1, 2014. The Ansary prize was presented in Houston with Ansary, Barbara Lucas, [[Ryan C. Crocker]], dean of the Bush school since January 2010, Barbara Bush, and Curt Viebranz in attendance with the former president. Bush directed $50,000 of the prize to the [[George Bush School of Government and Public Service|Bush school]] at [[Texas A&M University|Texas A&M]], and $25,000 will fund an animation about the [[Siege of Yorktown]] for Mt. Vernon.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602195113/http://www.mountvernon.org/ansaryprize |archivedate=June 2, 2014 |title=Former U.S. President Honored with Ansary Prize |url=http://www.mountvernon.org/ansaryprize |publisher=Mt. Vernon web page |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} Viebranz and Lucas represented Mount Vernon at the presentation.[http://www.mountvernon.org/about/senior-staff Senior staff], ''mountvernon.org''. Viebranz is identified as president and CEO of George Washington's Mount Vernon. Retrieved June 14, 2014.[http://www.mountvernon.org/video/watch/presidents-day-2014--barbara-lucas "Presidents Day 2014 - Barbara Lucas"], ''mountvernon.org''. Lucas is identified as regent of Mount Vernon's Ladies' Association. Retrieved June 14, 2014. On June 12, 2014, Bush fulfilled a long-standing promise by [[Parachuting|skydiving]] on his 90th birthday. He made the parachute jump from a helicopter near his home at 11:15 a.m. in Kennebunkport, Maine. The jump marked the eighth time the former president had skydived, including jumps on his 80th and 85th birthday as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2014/06/12/george-h-w-bush-skydiving-video/|title=George H. W. Bush SKYDIVES for His 90th Birthday!|publisher=[[TMZ]]|date=June 12, 2014|accessdate=July 2, 2014}} He had [[Twitter|tweeted]] about the incident prior to the jump, saying "It's a wonderful day in Maine — in fact, nice enough for a parachute jump."{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/theoval/2014/06/12/george-hw-bush-sky-dive-nbc-today-jenna-bush-hager/10362901/|title=George H.W. Bush takes one last skydive for 90th birthday|last=Jackson|first=David|work=[[USA Today]] |date=June 12, 2014|accessdate=July 2, 2014}}{{cite tweet|user=GeorgeHWBush|number=477061870478581760 |date=June 12, 2018 |title=It's a wonderful day in Maine -- in fact, nice enough for a parachute jump.}} [[File:Bushes and Pences C38RSFoVYAAZCI2.jpg|thumb|right|Bush and his wife [[Barbara Bush|Barbara]] with [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]] and his wife [[Karen Pence|Karen]] (far left), 2017. The woman adjacent to Mike Pence is his daughter [[Charlotte Pence|Charlotte.]]]] On December 7, 2016, Bush and former Senator [[Bob Dole]] commemorated the 75th anniversary of the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] by appearing at the Bush Center of [[Texas A&M University]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/07/politics/george-hw-bush-bob-dole-pearl-harbor-anniversary/index.html|title=George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole reunite for Pearl Harbor Anniversary|publisher=CNN|first=Terence|last=Burliij|date=December 7, 2016}} ====2016 election==== In November 2014, George W. confirmed that his father wanted Jeb to launch a presidential bid in [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016]].{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/2014/11/11/bush-father-son-want-jeb-bush-white-house/18873307/|title=Bush father, son want Jeb Bush to run for White House|date=November 11, 2014|publisher=azcentral.com}} Jeb decided to run for president, but struggled and withdrew from the Republican primary in the wave of anti-establishment sentiment led by [[Donald Trump]].{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/05/05/george-w-bush-trump-former-presidents/83962432/|title=Bush 41, 43 won't be endorsing Trump|first=Eliza|last=Collins|publisher=USA Today}} Both Bushes emerged as frequent critics of Trump's policies and speaking style, with Trump frequently criticizing George W. Bush's presidency. George H.W. Bush later said that he voted for the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, in the general election instead of Trump.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/11/04/both-bush-presidents-openly-condemned-trump-book-claims-one-even-voted-for-clinton/ |title=White House attacks legacies of both Bush presidents after reports they refused to vote for Trump |last=Selk |first=Avi |date=November 4, 2017 |publisher=''The Washington Post'' |access-date=November 4, 2017}} After Trump won the election, Bush sent him a congratulatory message.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2016/live-updates/general-election/real-time-updates-on-the-2016-election-voting-and-race-results/george-h-w-bushs-message-to-donald-trump/ |title=George H. W. Bush's message to Donald Trump|publisher=Washington Post|first=Lindsey|last=Bever|date=November 9, 2016}} ===Trump presidency=== On February 5, 2017, George and Barbara Bush participated in the coin toss for [[Super Bowl LI]].{{cite web |url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Former-President-Bush-fired-up-for-coin-toss-at-10909057.php |title=Former President Bush 'fired up' for coin toss at Houston's Super Bowl|author=George, Cindy|publisher=''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' |date=February 4, 2017|accessdate=February 5, 2017}} On May 18, 2017, after the death of [[Roger Ailes]], Bush tweeted, "He wasn't perfect, but Roger Ailes was my friend & I loved him. Not sure I would have been President w/o his great talent, loyal help. RIP."{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/18/politics/george-bush-roger-ailes-president/index.html|title=Bush 41 praises Ailes, says he's not sure he would have been president without him|first=Eugene|last=Scott|publisher=CNN|date=May 18, 2017}} On August 16, 2017, Bush and his son George W. released a joint statement in which they condemned the violence at the [[Unite the Right rally]].{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/08/16/george-h-w-bush-george-w-bush-we-must-reject-hatred-all-forms/572468001/|title=George H. W. Bush, George W. Bush: We must reject 'hatred in all forms'|first=Jessica|last=Estepa|publisher=USA Today|date=August 16, 2017}} On September 7, 2017, Bush partnered with former presidents Carter, Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama to work with [[One America Appeal]] to help the victims of [[Hurricane Harvey]] and [[Hurricane Irma]] in the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] and [[Texas]] communities.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/349993-former-presidents-add-irma-recovery-to-fundraising-appeal|title=Former presidents fundraise for Irma disaster relief|last=Shelbourne|first=Mallory|date=September 10, 2017|work=The Hill|accessdate=11 September 2017}} ===Health=== In 1991, ''The New York Times'' revealed that Bush was suffering from [[Graves' disease]], a non-contagious thyroid condition that his wife Barbara also had.{{cite news |last1=Altman |first1=Lawrence |title=In Strange Twist, Bush Is Suffering From Same Gland Disease as Wife |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/us/in-strange-twist-bush-is-suffering-from-same-gland-disease-as-wife.html |accessdate=June 5, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=May 10, 1991}} On February 24, 2000, Bush was standing at a reception for 90 minutes when he felt lightheaded. He was admitted to a hospital with an irregular heartbeat.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/25/us/the-2000-campaign-ex-president-falls-ill.html|title=THE 2000 CAMPAIGN; Ex-President Falls Ill|date=February 25, 2000|agency=Associated Press}} When Bush was released three days later, his doctors said that he had retained the irregularity in his heartbeat.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/27/us/national-news-briefs-elder-bush-is-released-after-more-heart-tests.html|title=Elder Bush Is Released After More Heart Tests|date=February 24, 2000|work=[[The New York Times]]}} On March 11, 2007, Bush fainted on a golf course and was admitted to the Eisenhower Medical Center in [[Rancho Mirage]], but was released the following morning.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2007/03/12/Presidents-father-faints-on-golf-course/41821173725180/|title=President's father faints on golf course|date=March 12, 2007|publisher=UPI}} Bush suffers from [[Parkinsonism|vascular parkinsonism]], a form of [[Parkinson's disease]] that has forced him to use a motorized scooter or wheelchair since at least 2012.{{cite web|title=Photo P012712PS-0676|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/whitehouse/6773105167/in/photostream/|date=January 27, 2012|publisher=The Whitehouse|accessdate=April 24, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Updegrove|first1=Mark K.|title=An Exclusive Conversation with President and Mrs. Bush|url=https://parade.com/123684/markupdegrove/15-george-hw-bush-family-is-what-matters/|accessdate=February 15, 2017|work=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]|date=July 15, 2012}} In July 2015, Bush suffered a severe neck injury. At age 91 in October that year, he was wearing a neck brace in his first public engagement since the accident when he threw the [[ceremonial first pitch]] for the [[Houston Astros]] at [[Minute Maid Park]].{{cite news|last1=McAfee|first1=Tierney|title=PHOTO: George H.W. Bush Throws Out First Pitch at Astros Playoff Game in First Public Appearance Since Neck Injury|url=http://www.people.com/article/george-bush-throws-first-pitch-houston-astros-game-neck-injury|accessdate=January 31, 2016|work=People|date=October 12, 2015}} Bush wrote a letter to president-elect [[Donald Trump]] in January 2017 to inform him that because of his poor health, he would not be able to attend [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|Trump's inauguration]] on January 20; he gave him his best wishes. On January 18, he was admitted to the intensive care unit at [[Houston Methodist Hospital]], where he was sedated for a procedure to treat an acute respiratory problem that was stemming from pneumonia.{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Feliks|title=George HW Bush sends personal note to Donald Trump on why he can't attend inauguration|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/george-hw-bush-donald-trump-inauguration-letter-president-attendance-a7534221.html|accessdate=January 18, 2017|work=The Independent|date=January 18, 2017}} Three months later, he experienced a recurrence of pneumonia and was hospitalized.{{cite web|title=Former President George HW Bush hospitalised in Houston|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/18/former-president-george-hw-bush-hospitalised-houston/|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=April 19, 2017|language=en|date=April 19, 2017}} On April 22, 2018—the day after his wife's funeral—the former president was hospitalized with a blood infection.{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/texas/2018/04/23/george-h-w-bush-admitted-houston-hospital-blood-infection|title=George H.W. Bush admitted to Houston hospital for blood infection|date=April 23, 2018|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/23/george-hw-bush-admitted-hospital-days-wifes-death/|title=George H.W. Bush admitted to hospital days after wife's death|first=Telegraph|last=Reporters|date=April 23, 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}} The infection led to [[sepsis]].https://edition.cnn.com/2018/04/23/politics/george-hw-bush/index.html One month later, he was briefly hospitalized again, after experiencing fatigue and low blood pressure.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/27/politics/george-hw-bush-hospital-maine/index.html|title=George H.W. Bush hospitalized|last=CNN|first=Maegan Vazquez,|work=CNN|access-date=May 27, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/ct-president-george-hw-bush-hospitalized-20180527-story,amp.html|title=Former president George H.W. Bush is hospitalized again, spokesman says|last=Phillips|first=Kristine|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=May 27, 2018}} ===Sexual misconduct allegations=== In October 2017, during the [[Me too (hashtag)|#MeToo movement]], actress [[Heather Lind]] accused Bush of [[groping]] her and telling an inappropriate joke. Several other women subsequently made similar allegations, including [[Christina Baker Kline]] and Roslyn Corrigan (who was 16 years old at the time of the alleged incident). Bush has apologized for these incidents through his spokesman, Jim McGrath.{{cite news|first=Tom|last=Porter|url=https://www.newsweek.com/george-hw-bush-apologizes-after-sex-assault-allegation-692368|title=George H.W. Bush Apologizes After Actress Heather Lind Accuses Him of Sexual Assault|work=Newsweek|date=October 25, 2017|accessdate=September 14, 2018}}{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/10/26/560148936/george-h-w-bush-acknowledges-groping-multiple-women |title=George H.W. Bush Responds to Groping Allegations: The Two-Way |work=NPR |date=October 26, 2017 |accessdate=October 29, 2017|first=James|last=Doubek}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2017/11/seventh_woman_alleges_george_hw_bush_groped_her_du.html|title=Seventh woman alleges George H.W. Bush groped her during photo op|website=[[NJ.com]]|date=November 17, 2017|first=Amy|last=Kuperinsky}} === Longevity === On November 25, 2017, Bush became the [[List of Presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived U.S. president]] when he surpassed the 93 years and 165 days lifespan of [[Gerald Ford]], who died in 2006.{{cite news| last=Bowden| first=John| date=November 25, 2017| title=Bush 41 becomes longest-living president in US history| url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/361795-bush-41-becomes-longest-living-president-in-us-history | work=The Hill | location=Washington, D.C. | access-date=November 25, 2017}} Bush is currently {{age in years and days|1924|6|12}} old, and he is the nation's [[Living presidents and vice presidents of the United States|oldest living president as well as the oldest living vice president]]. He is also the first president to reach the age of 94, reaching that milestone on June 12, 2018.{{Cite web |url=http://time.com/5310620/george-hw-bush-first-president-94-years-old-birthday/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614021607/http://time.com/5310620/george-hw-bush-first-president-94-years-old-birthday/ |archive-date=June 14, 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The [[List of Vice Presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived U.S. vice president]] is [[John Nance Garner]], who died on November 7, 1967, 15 days short of his 99th birthday.{{cite news| last=Lewis| first=Janna| date=January 22, 2009| title=Texans who were presidents, vice-presidents| url=http://www.forthoodsentinel.com/leisure/texans-who-were-presidents-vice-presidents/article_6b538cd2-aa2a-53a2-bc6f-6df30cfadf71.html| work=Fort Hood Sentinel|location=Fort Hood, Texas|accessdate=April 22, 2018}} ==Presidential library== {{Main|George Bush Presidential Library}} [[File:George Bush Presidential Library.jpg|thumb|right|The George Bush Presidential Library on the west campus of Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas]] The George Bush Presidential Library is the nation's tenth [[presidential library]] and was built between 1995 and 1997. It contains the presidential and vice presidential papers of Bush and the vice presidential papers of [[Dan Quayle]].{{cite web |title=The Birth of the Tenth Presidential Library: The Bush Presidential Materials Project, 1993–1994|publisher=George Bush Presidential Library |url=http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/giq.html |accessdate=March 22, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070410185146/http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/giq.html |archivedate = April 10, 2007}} It was dedicated on November 6, 1997 and opened to the public shortly thereafter; the architectural firm of [[Hellmuth, Obata and Kassabaum]] designed the complex. The George Bush Presidential Library and Museum is located on a {{convert|90|acre|m2|adj=on}} site on the west campus of [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]], on a plaza adjoining the Presidential Conference Center and the Texas A&M Academic Center. The Library operates under [[National Archives and Records Administration|NARA]]'s administration and the provisions of the Presidential Libraries Act of 1955. The [[George Bush School of Government and Public Service|Bush School of Government and Public Service]] is a graduate [[public policy school]] at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas. The graduate school is part of the presidential library complex, and offers four programs: two master's degree programs (''Public Service and Administration'', and ''International Affairs'') and three certificate programs (''Advanced International Affairs'', ''Nonprofit Management'', and ''[[Homeland Security]]''). The Master in International Affairs (MIA) degree program offers concentrations in either National Security and Diplomacy or International Development and Economic Policy. ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|George H. W. Bush}} * [[Electoral history of George H. W. {{Wiktionary|GPS}}
'''[[GPS]]''' is the Global Positioning System, a satellite-based navigation system.

'''GPS''' may also refer to:
{{TOC right}}

==Technology==
* [[GPS navigation device]], especially an automotive navigation system
* [[Generalized processor sharing]], an algorithm to fairly share computer processing time
* [[General Problem Solver]], a 1959 computer program
* [[GNAT Programming Studio]], a software development package

==Organizations==
* [[Crossroads GPS]] (Grassroots Policy Strategies), a nonprofit corporation that works in conjunction with the Super PAC American Crossroads
* [[Fusion GPS]], American commercial and strategic research firm
* [[Ghana Prisons Service]]
* [[GPS (band)]], a progressive rock band
* [[GPS Rugby]], an Australian rugby union club
* [[Geirus Policies and Standards committee]], a body of the Rabbinical Council of America
* [[Gabungan Parti Sarawak]], a Malaysian political coalition based in Sarawak

===Education===
* [[Gilbert Public Schools]], a school district in Gilbert, Arizona, US
* [[Girls Preparatory School]], an all-girls prep school in Chattanooga, Tennessee, US
* [[Athletic Association of the Great Public Schools of New South Wales]], an association of private boys' schools, Australia
* [[Great Public Schools Association of Queensland Inc.]], an association of nine Australian schools
* [[Grosse Pointe South High School]], a public high school in Grosse Pointe, Michigan, US
* The [[School of Global Policy and Strategy]], an institute of international studies at the [[University of California, San Diego]]

===Medicine===
* [[Goodpasture syndrome]], a rare autoimmune disease
* [[genome-wide polygenic scores]] a technique used to assess effects of clusters of genes on inherited traits such as intelligence. <!-- <ref>{{cite news|last1=Ridley|first1=Matt|title=Forget private school, it’s all in the genes|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/comment/forget-private-school-its-all-in-thegenes-hzxfj8nwd|accessdate=27 March 2018|work=Times (paywall)|date=26 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> -->

==Other uses==
* [[Seymour Airport]] (IATA code), Galápagos Islands, Ecuador
* ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'' (''Global Public Square''), a CNN television show
* [[Geometrical Products Specification]], an international standard for geometric dimensioning and tolerancing
* [[Genealogical Proof Standard]] (see also [[Cluster genealogy]])
* [[GPS (Maluma song)|"GPS" (Maluma song)]]
* "Var är jag", renamed to "GPS", a song by Basshunter from his ''[[LOL (Basshunter album)|LOL <(^^,)>]]'' album

==See also==
* Grams of protein per dollar (gP/$), a means of representing the cost of [[amino acid]]s in a food product
